{{Philosophy sidebar}}

−
'''Ethics''' (also '''moral philosophy''') is the branch of [[philosophy]] that involves systematizing, defending, and recommending concepts of right and wrong [[action (philosophy)|conduct]].<ref name="iep.utm.edu">''Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy'': [http://www.iep.utm.edu/ethics/ "Ethics"]</ref> The term ''ethics'' derives from the [[Ancient Greek]] word ἠθικός ''ethikos'', which is derived from the word ἦθος ''[[ethos]]'' ([[habit]], “custom”). The branch of philosophy [[Axiology]] comprises the sub-branches of Ethics and [[Aesthetics]], each concerned with concepts of value.<ref>''[[Random House Unabridged Dictionary]]'': [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/axiology Entry on Axiology.]</ref>
+
'''Ethics''' (also '''Moral philosophy''') is the branch of [[philosophy]] that involves systematizing, defending, and recommending concepts of right and wrong [[action (philosophy)|conduct]].<ref name="iep.utm.edu">''Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy'': [http://www.iep.utm.edu/ethics/ "Ethics"]</ref> The term ''ethics'' derives from the [[Ancient Greek]] word ἠθικός ''ethikos'', which is derived from the word ἦθος ''[[ethos]]'' ([[habit]], “custom”). The branch of philosophy [[Axiology]] comprises the sub-branches of Ethics and [[Aesthetics]], each concerned with concepts of value.<ref>''[[Random House Unabridged Dictionary]]'': [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/axiology Entry on Axiology.]</ref>
    −
As a branch of philosophy, ethics investigates the questions: “What is the best way for humans to live?” and “What kinds of actions are right or wrong in particular circumstances?” In practice, Ethics seeks to resolve questions of human morality, by defining concepts such as [[good and evil]], right and [[wrong]], [[virtue]] and [[vice]], [[justice]] and [[crime]]. As a field of intellectual enquiry, Moral philosophy also is related to the fields of [[moral psychology]], [[descriptive ethics]], and [[value theory]].
+
As a branch of philosophy, Ethics investigates the questions: “What is the best way for people to live?” and “What [[action (philosophy)|actions] are right or wrong in particular circumstances?” In practice, Ethics seeks to resolve questions of human morality, by defining concepts such as [[good and evil]], right and [[wrong]], [[virtue]] and [[vice]], [[justice]] and [[crime]]. As a field of intellectual enquiry, Moral philosophy also is related to the fields of [[moral psychology]], [[descriptive ethics]], and [[value theory]].
    −
;The study of Ethics is in three areas:
+
;Ethics is studied in three areas:
    −
#[[Meta-ethics]], concerning the theoretical definitions and references of moral propositions, and how their [[truth value]]s can be determined
+
#[[Meta-ethics]], concern the theoretical definitions and references of moral propositions, and how their [[truth value]]s can be determined
−
#[[Normative ethics]], concerning the practical means of determining a moral course of action
+
#[[Normative ethics]], concern the practical means of determining a moral course of action
−
#[[Applied ethics]], concerning ethical theory that asks: What a person is obligated to do in a specific situation? and What is a person to do in a particular domain of action?<ref name="iep.utm.edu"/>
+
#[[Applied ethics]], concern ethical theory, which asks: “What is a person is obligated to do, in a specific situation?” and “What is a person to do in a particular domain of action?”<ref name="iep.utm.edu"/>
